snippet: Boko Haram, the Nigerian group that has carried out mass kidnappings, was rejected long ago by mainstream Muslims, but its recent abductions appeared too much even for fellow militants to condone.
abstract: Kidnapping of more than 200 Nigerian schoolgirls by radical Islamist group Boko Haram appears too much even for fellow militants to condone; group's proclivity for violence against civilians is strikingly inconsistent with current push by Al Qaeda's leaders to avoid such deaths for fear of alienating potential supporters.

byline.original: By ADAM NOSSITER and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
byline.contributor: Adam Nossiter reported from Abuja, and David D. Kirkpatrick from Cairo. Mayy El Sheikh contributed reporting from Cairo.

lead_paragraph: Boko Haram, the Nigerian group that has carried out mass kidnappings, was rejected long ago by mainstream Muslims, but its recent abductions appeared too much even for fellow militants to condone.

headline.main: Abduction of Girls an Act Not Even Al Qaeda Can Condone
headline.print_headline: Abduction of Girls an Act Not Even Al Qaeda Can Condone
